comments.body:
For "Plain" style `UITableView` the section header snaps to the top as the table view scrolls. To achieve that in flutter the headers need to be sliver widgets instead of regular widgets (see https://api.flutter.dev/flutter/widgets/ScrollView-class.html). Unfortunately it does not work if you put a sliver widget in `header` here, they have to be direct children of the scroll view, something like:
```dart
CustomScrollView(
  slivers: <Widget>[
    header1,
    SliverToBoxAdapter(child: CupertinoFormSection(...)),
    footer1,
    header2,
    SliverToBoxAdapter(child: CupertinoFormSection(...)),
    footer2,
  ],
) 
```
I think It would be more consistent to just leave `header` or `footer` out in this widget, and let the developer decide how these components should be put together.

There's a difference between the traditional table view header and the settings-like forms. If you go to settings -> general -> about, you will see some headers that do not snap to the frame. This is normal behavior for forms I think. cc @xster
I think this is ok. The normal uitableview (which this is not) is indeed more complicated.
Oh didn't know SwiftUI had additional UI components. Taking a look.
I think we need a `footer` field then? My concern is that developers that have SwiftUI background will put this in a `ListView` and expect the header to magically snap.
